src:
ENTREVISTA
Julia Medina: "Era tímida, pero ya he dejado de serlo"
Tras salir de 'OT', la gaditana lanza su primer disco, 'No dejo de bailar'
03 Nov 2019, 15:54 by Eugènia Marfà
Julia Medina (Cádiz, 1994) saltó a la fama gracias a su participación en la última edición de 'Operación Triunfo', el formato televisivo que ha enamorado a tantos espectadores. Durante los tres meses que estuvo en el concurso, donde quedó quinta, destacó por su voz cálida y dulce. Tras todo un año de aprendizaje al salir de la Academia, ahora presenta su primer disco, 'No dejo de bailar', 10 canciones que reflejan honestidad y verdad. En el proyecto han estado junto a ella compositores como Andrés Suárez, David Santisteban y Ricky Rivera.
"Me descubro a mí misma"
La cantante ha tenido muy presente el 'talent show' a la hora de elegir 'No dejo de bailar' como nombre del disco. "Cuando estaba en la Academia, tenía que bailar mucho. Es algo que me encanta, pero no se me da del todo bien. Me preguntaba: ¿cómo lo estaré haciendo? Bueno, estoy aprendiendo. Entonces lo comparé con hacer un disco. ¿Cómo se hace un disco? ¡Haciéndolo! Me pareció una comparación bonita".
Julia siempre ha tenido claro que quería hacer un disco, ya fuese con una discográfica o por ella misma. Durante el paso por la Academia y, sobre todo, al salir de ella, ha tenido tiempo para componer y conocerse más como cantante. "Ha sido un tiempo de aprendizaje. Todo artista, cuando está empezando, no sabe cuál es su sello hasta que hace música. Al final, con el disco me descubro un poco a mí misma", explica. "Este es un disco homogéneo, todo tiene sentido. Pero hay dos vertientes: una un poco más clásica y melódica, y otra más de cantautor", añade. El 8 de febrero tendrá su presentación en directo en la Sala 2 de Apolo y después recorrerá otras ciudades. 



En 'No dejo de bailar', demuestra su valía como compositora. Para escribir las canciones, ha contado con la ayuda de artistas como Carmen Boza y Pedro Guerra. "Ya los admiraba de antes, porque me gustan como compositores y como artistas, y se me dio la oportunidad de componer con ellos. La colaboración surgió como algo natural".
Julia no quiere transmitir ningún mensaje en especial. "Cada una tiene su historia detrás. Son cosas que me pasan y cosas que siento. Las he grabado para que la gente, al escucharlas, quizá sienta las emociones que yo he sentido".
A pesar de que 'No me despedí' con Carmen Boza es su favorita, escogió 'Dime' como carta de presentación. "Porque representa esta vertiente más pop, melódica y clásica. Aunque es una balada, tiene mucha fuerza y me permitía demostrar más vocalmente".


Julia Medina.  Elisenda pons

"Esto vale la pena"
La vida de Julia siempre ha estado ligada a la música. Antes de presentarse a 'OT', ya cantaba en hoteles. "El programa es una ventana muy grande donde exponerse y pensé que me iría bien para mi carrera". 
Recuerda el concurso como una experiencia "muy intensa y bonita", que le ha servido para crecer y aprender como persona y artista. "Era tímida, y este año he hecho un cursillo que me ha ayudado a dejar de serlo. Ahora ya no me cuesta nada relacionarme con la gente. Y musicalmente, he aprendido muchísimo, sobre todo después de la Academia porque me he reunido con algunos compositores, de los cuales me he enriquecido mucho". Sin embargo, afirma que sigue siendo la misma persona que antes de vivir esta experiencia.
Antes de su paso por el programa, Julia tenía muchos prejuicios hacia la industria musical. "Me costaba un poco encajarlo. Pero cuando llegué a Universal y me dieron la oportunidad de hacer lo que quisiera, ahí cambió un poco mi visión, y pensé: ¡Esto vale la pena!".
Para ella, la notoriedad y la exposición son difíciles de gestionar, pero van de la mano de la música. "Los primeros días tras salir de la Academia fueron un 'shock' emocional, pero ya he tenido tiempo para asimilarlo todo. Me sorprendió que la realidad que nosotros habíamos vivido en el programa estuviera multiplicada fuera, todo era más intenso. Nosotros, al final, estábamos viviendo nuestro campamento de verano, y fuera era todo una locura. Pero ahora ya tengo los pies en la tierra".  
Mensaje para los nuevos aspirantes
La gaditana tiene también un mensaje para aquellas personas que se presentan al nuevo 'casting' de 'OT 2020': "He visto mucha gente derrotada porque no la han cogido y, realmente, es una experiencia más que tienes que guardarte, y es cuando tienes que decir: ¡No voy a dejarlo y voy a seguir luchando por la música! Yo lo habría hecho. Si no me hubiesen cogido, quizá ahora estaría grabando mi disco en un estudio pequeño, o algo por el estilo. Si quieres algo, tienes que ir a por ello".
Ella lo ha hecho. Durante este tiempo, no ha dejado de bailar para llegar hasta aquí, en plena promoción del disco con firmas en distintas ciudades de España, y con el estreno de la gira el próximo febrero.

text:
INTERVIEW
Julia Medina: "I was shy, but I have stopped being so"
After leaving 'OT', Cádiz releases her first album, 'I don't stop dancing'
03 Nov 2019, 15:54 by Eugènia Marfà
Julia Medina (Cádiz, 1994) rose to fame thanks to her participation in the latest edition of 'Operation Triunfo', the television format that has enamored so many spectators. During the three months he was in the contest, where he was fifth, he stood out for his warm and sweet voice. After a whole year of learning when leaving the Academy, he now presents his first album, 'I don't stop dancing', 10 songs that reflect honesty and truth. Composers such as Andrés Suárez, David Santisteban and Ricky Rivera have been with her on the project.
"I discover myself"
The singer has been very aware of the 'talent show' when choosing 'I do not stop dancing' as the name of the album. "When I was at the Academy, I had to dance a lot. It's something I love, but I'm not quite right. I was wondering: how will I be doing it? Well, I'm learning. Then I compared it to making a record. How do you make a record? Doing it! It seemed like a nice comparison. "
Julia has always been clear that she wanted to make a record, either with a record label or by herself. During his time at the Academy and, above all, when he left it, he had time to compose and become more known as a singer. "It has been a learning time. Every artist, when he is starting, does not know what his label is until he makes music. In the end, with the album I discover myself a little," he explains. "This is a homogeneous album, everything makes sense. But there are two aspects: one a bit more classical and melodic, and another one as a singer-songwriter," he adds. On February 8 he will have his live presentation in Hall 2 of Apollo and then tour other cities.



In 'I don't stop dancing', she demonstrates her worth as a composer. To write the songs, he has had the help of artists like Carmen Boza and Pedro Guerra. "I already admired them before, because I like them as composers and as artists, and I was given the opportunity to compose with them. The collaboration emerged as something natural."
Julia doesn't want to convey any special message. "Each one has its history behind. These are things that happen to me and things that I feel. I have recorded them so that people, listening to them, may feel the emotions that I have felt."
Although 'I didn't say goodbye' with Carmen Boza is her favorite, she chose 'Tell me' as a cover letter. "Because it represents this more pop, melodic and classical side. Although it is a ballad, it has a lot of strength and allowed me to demonstrate more vocally."


Julia Medina Elisenda pons

"This is worth it"
Julia's life has always been linked to music. Before introducing himself to 'OT', he already sang in hotels. "The program is a very large window to expose myself and I thought I would do well for my career."
Remember the contest as a "very intense and beautiful" experience, which has helped him grow and learn as a person and artist. "I was shy, and this year I have done a workshop that has helped me to stop being one. Now it costs me nothing to interact with people. And musically, I have learned a lot, especially after the Academy because I have met with some composers, of which I have become very rich. " However, he affirms that he is still the same person as before living this experience.
Before going through the program, Julia had a lot of prejudices towards the music industry. "It was a little difficult to fit in. But when I arrived at Universal and they gave me the opportunity to do what I wanted, there changed my vision a little, and I thought: This is worth it!"
For her, notoriety and exposure are difficult to manage, but go hand in hand with music. "The first days after leaving the Academy were an emotional shock, but I have had time to assimilate everything. I was surprised that the reality that we had lived in the program was multiplied outside, everything was more intense. We, in the end , We were living our summer camp, and outside it was all crazy. But now I have my feet on the ground. "
Message for new applicants
The Cadiz also has a message for those people who are presented to the new 'casting' of 'OT 2020': "I have seen many people defeated because they have not caught it and, really, it is an experience that you have to keep, and that is when you have to say: I'm not going to leave it and I'm going to keep fighting for music! I would have done it. If they hadn't taken me, maybe now I would be recording my album in a small studio, or something like that. If you want something, you have to go for it. "
She has done it. During this time, he has not stopped dancing to get here, in full promotion of the album with signatures in different cities of Spain, and with the premiere of the tour next February.
